items.content_html:
Summary

Add compatibility notes regarding Samsung devices incorrectly reporting (hover: hover) on touch-screens.

Test results and supporting details

Tested on Galaxy S10e and S8, and Samsung A12 and A71.

  • https://crbug.com/940256
  • https://www.ctrl.blog/entry/css-media-hover-samsung.html
  • https://forum.unity.com/threads/android-input-doesnt-work-because-two-touchscreens-are-detected.949599/
  • https://github.com/moonlight-stream/moonlight-android/blob/8a63b614955a726fc27c89bcf3699022214756d7/app/src/main/java/com/limelight/binding/input/capture/AndroidNativePointerCaptureProvider.java#L31
items.title: Samsung incorrectly reporets hover:hover

items.content_html:
Summary

Removing the suggested support of the content-visibility CSS property for Safari and Safari iOS as it is not yet supported.

Test results and supporting details

Tested manually on Safari 15.4 on Mac and iOS Safari 15.4 on real device and XCode simulator using the Safari WebInspector ("devtools").

Supporting information: See also in caniuse: https://caniuse.com/css-content-visibility
items.title: content-visibility update - No support in Safari

items.content_html:
counter-reset has this example on the top. The results from Chrome, Firebox 81 and earlier, and everything else are on the left, the results from Firefox 82 are on the right.

All of those chapters are h2 headings, and the counter-reset is applied to the second chapter "The pool of tears". In the context of just this example you'd think that the Chrome was correct and that the subsequent items should follow the siblings, but in fact it is in violation of spec.

The reason is that each element gets a copy of the counter(s) of it's ancestors "first" if a counter is not explicitly applied. When you call counter-reset on an element you reset the counter on that specific element (create a new counter), not on every other (subsequent) elements (from comment in bug).
So while the selected counter should change, the other siblings keep their original counter.

This might seem odd, but normally you'd call counter-reset on the parent, not on some arbitrary element mid way through.

To get the more intuitive behaviour we're seeing in chrome you could call counter-set. My understanding is that this would set the counter on the element and on all subsequent elements in the same scope, though I could be wrong [ @MatsPalmgren could you confirm all that? i.e. both counter-reset and set statements ]

Anyway, as this is a spec fix I have done this as a "negative subfeature", meaning that use_reset_for_siblings has been added as a deprecated subfeature that reflects the non-spec behaviour from the first version. This is still supported by Chrome et al, but Firefox has version_removed from FF82. Eventually all things should match the spec, and this would eventually be removed.
I called this use_reset_for_siblings which I hope is a reasonable name for the bad behaviour, with description "Reset counter used instead of ancestor for subsequent sibling elements."`, Maybe better name would be "counter_reset_affects_siblings"?

FYI

  1. This follows on from mdn/content#13513 - I want to confirm that I have the problem well understood before I review and update that.
  2. The example used in image above is also problematic and a fix has been proposed by Mats in mdn/content#6277. I'll get to that eventually.

@ddbeck Thoughts? I really want @MatsPalmgren advice too. This is an ongoing source of confusion.
items.title: FF82 CSS counter-reset spec fix

items.content_html:
Summary

Update information about text-emphasis properties which are no longer prefixed in Chromium and Edge.

Test results and supporting details

I've tested things in Chrome 99 and Edge 101.

This is the commit that unprefixed them: https://chromiumdash.appspot.com/commit/a0d4ce22e17b2cdc22311d731c8fe9cca9ae3a8e

Related issues

See mdn/content#14542
items.title: Update text-emphasis properties information

items.content_html:
Summary

Safari on iOS does not support ::selection

Test results and supporting details

Verified in iOS Simulator - iPhone 13 - iOS 15.2 using https://quirksmode.org/css/selectors/selection.html

Also corroborated by https://caniuse.com/css-selection
items.title: Safari on iOS does not support ::selection

items.content_html:
This PR fixes #7354 by replacing all of Opera Android's flag data with false statements using the substitution regex below, followed by
marking Opera as not accepting flags to prevent regressions. A consistency follow-up is then performed, along with a manual removal of a
few flag entries too challenging to remove with a regex script.

Regex Used for Mass Replacement: "opera_android": { (\s+)"version_added": (.*), \s+(?:"version_removed": (.*), \s+)?"flags": \[([^\]]* )*(\s+)\] (\s+)}
-> "opera_android": { $1"version_added": false $5}

Depends on: #15643
items.title: Remove all flag data for Opera Android

items.content_html:
This PR performs two operations relating to the GlobalEventHandlers mixin.

First, the mixin is de-mixed and separated into their individual interfaces. This includes Document, Window, HTMLElement,
MathMLElement, and SVGElement.

Second, the event handlers are converted to the new naming convention, and URLs are also updated. In the process, duplicates are removed.

Possible conflict with #15677.
items.title: Demix GlobalEventHandlers; adapt to new events structure

items.content_html:
Summary

Add missing 402 HTTP status code reserved for future use.

Test results and supporting details

It already has an MDN page: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/402

Related issues

N/A
items.title: feat: add 402 Payment Required status code

items.content_html:
This PR removes the WindowEventHandlers mixin. The events are placed in Window.json already.

The HTMLBodyElement, HTMLFrameSetElement, and SVGSVGElement interfaces contain the event handler properties as aliases but they are targeted on the window object.

Further, the event content attributes are removed from the HTML body element data to avoid duplication.
items.title: Remove WindowEventHandlers mixin; remove duplicate event content attributes on <body>
